item.title: Hong Kong Steps Up Defense of FX Peg as Fixed Range Tested Again
item.description: Hong Kong’s de-facto central bank ramped up purchases of the city’s currency as it sought to defend a peg that has been strained by volatility in the greenback.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Burgess

media:content.media:description: An employee counts Hong Kong one-thousand dollar banknotes at the Hang Seng Bank Ltd. headquarters in Hong Kong, China, on Tuesday, April 16, 2019. The Hong Kong dollar’s one-month historical volatility climbed to the highest since early February as traders were whiplashed by the currency’s price swings amid declining liquidity. With the city’s de facto central bank having spent $2.8 billion in March to defend the peg to the U.S. dollar, Hong Kong’s aggregate balance has dropped and interbank rates have soared.

item.title: Starmer Emerges From UK Welfare Fight Weaker and Billions in Red
item.description: Keir Starmer dramatically abandoned his flagship welfare reforms to avoid a historic defeat, leaving the UK prime minister’s authority badly damaged and his government facing a widening fiscal hole to fill.
item.dc:creator: Joe Mayes, Lucy White, Ailbhe Rea

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer, UK prime minister, during a meeting with Dick Schoof, Netherlands' prime minister, not pictured, at 10 Downing Street in London, UK, on Thursday, Feb. 6, 2025. The closer the Labour government aligns the British economy with the EU's — as it promised to do in July's election — the less room it has for maneuver to accommodate US demands on trade.

item.title: Lula Fights to Tax the Rich in Preview of 2026 Election Battle

item.description: US job openings unexpectedly rose in May to the highest level since November, largely fueled by leisure and hospitality, and layoffs declined, pointing to a stable labor market despite economic uncertainty.

item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council member Madis Muller said the economy doesn’t currently justify interest rates that stimulate growth, allowing officials to take a pause from easing to gauge how activity withstands various threats.

item.description: Britain’s fiscal watchdog said it has been too optimistic about the country’s medium-term growth prospects and promised a full evaluation of the economy’s speed limit over the summer in what will be a crucial moment for Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves.

item.title: Citi Sees Zambian Kwacha Rally Extending If Copper-Price Link Restored
item.description: Zambia’s currency appears set for sustained gains if its correlation with the copper price is restored, Citigroup Inc said.

item.title: BOE’s Bailey Says Low UK Debt Making High Rates Less Effective
item.description: Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey said high interest rates are having less of an impact on inflation because of Britain’s low levels of debt among both businesses and consumers.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees

media:content.media:description: Bank of England Governor Andrew Baily speaks during a policy panel at the ECB Forum on Central Banking in Sintra, Portugal, on July 1.

item.title: BOJ’s Ueda Still Needs More Information to Decide Next Rate Hike
item.description: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda ramped up his message that he is going to wait for additional data to make a judgment on the next monetary policy decision, signaling that he’s in no rush to raise borrowing costs.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka, Francine Lacqua

media:content.media:description: Kazuo Ueda, governor of the Bank of Japan (BOJ), leaves a news conference at the central bank's headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, on Tuesday, June 17, 2025. The BOJ left its benchmark rate unchanged and unveiled a plan to slow its withdrawal from the bond market from next year in a sign of caution following heightened market volatility.

item.title: Powell Reiterates Fed Would Have Cut More If Not for Tariffs
item.description: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell repeated that the US central bank probably would have cut rates further this year absent President Donald Trump’s expanded use of tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Amara Omeokwe

item.title: US Manufacturing Activity Contracted in June for a Fourth Month
item.description: US factory activity contracted in June for a fourth consecutive month as orders and employment shrank at a faster pace, extending the malaise in manufacturing.
item.dc:creator: Nazmul Ahasan

media:content.media:description: A worker arc welds a metal door during production at the Metal Manufacturing Co. facility in Sacramento, California, US, on Tuesday, May 27, 2025. The US Census Bureau is scheduled to release factory orders figures on June 3.

item.title: BOK’s Rhee Says Tariff Impact on Growth Remains Policy Challenge
item.description: The Bank of Korea remains concerned at the tariff impact on economic expansion rather than inflation and is judging how to keep cutting interest rates while weighing stability risks, according to Governor Rhee Chang-yong.
item.dc:creator: Heesu Lee, Francine Lacqua

media:content.media:description: Governor of the Bank of Korea Rhee Chang-yong starts a monetary policy meeting at the central bank's headquarters in Seoul, on April 17.

item.title: EU to Accept Trump Universal Tariff But Seeks Key Exemptions
item.description: The European Union is willing to accept a trade arrangement with the US that includes a 10% universal tariff on many of the bloc’s exports, but wants the US to commit to lower rates than that on key sectors such as pharmaceuticals, alcohol, semiconductors and commercial aircraft.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero, Alberto Nardelli

item.title: Chile Economic Activity Slips, Boosting Case for Rate Cuts
